citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The program of veterinary care calls for the attending veterinarian to visit the premises twice a year. The attending
veterinarian was last out in November of 2023. Not following the program of veterinary care and having the attending
veterinarian visit the premises as per the instructions in the program of veterinary care doesn't ensure that adequate
veterinary care is being provided to the animals on site. An appointment must be made to have the attending veterinarian
conduct a visit to the facility. Correct by 1/19/24.

An enclosure housing a serval had an outdoor gate where one of the posts at the bottom was rusted through. It had
jagged edges. Jagged edges can cause injury to the animal. The rusted out section could create a large enough hole
where the serval could potentially escape from its enclosure. In addition the rusted area doesn't allow for it to be properly
cleaned and/or sanitized. The rusted area of the fence must be repaired so there are no longer any jagged edges or holes
in the fencing.

On the northeast corner of the perimeter fence, the fencing of the serval enclosure is not 3 feet away from the perimeter
fencing. It is approximately one foot away in this section. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter
fence. Perimeter fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the
Administrator. The licensee must fix the fencing in this area to ensure the perimeter fence is 3 feet away from the primary
enclosure or the licensee must get approval from the Administrator for the perimeter fencing to remain the way it is
currently set up. Correct by 1/19/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The program of veterinary care calls for the attending veterinarian to visit the premises twice a year. The attending 
veterinarian was last out in November of 2023. Not following the program of veterinary care and having the attending 
veterinarian visit the premises as per the instructions in the program of veterinary care doesn't ensure that adequate 
veterinary care is being provided to the animals on site. An appointment must be made to have the attending veterinarian 
conduct a visit to the facility. Correct by 1/19/24. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure housing a serval had an outdoor gate where one of the posts at the bottom was rusted through. It had 
jagged edges. Jagged edges can cause injury to the animal. The rusted out section could create a large enough hole 
where the serval could potentially escape from its enclosure. In addition the rusted area doesn't allow for it to be properly 
cleaned and/or sanitized. The rusted area of the fence must be repaired so there are no longer any jagged edges or holes 
in the fencing. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
On the northeast corner of the perimeter fence, the fencing of the serval enclosure is not 3 feet away from the perimeter 
fencing. It is approximately one foot away in this section. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary 
enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter 
fence. Perimeter fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the 
Administrator. The licensee must fix the fencing in this area to ensure the perimeter fence is 3 feet away from the primary 
enclosure or the licensee must get approval from the Administrator for the perimeter fencing to remain the way it is 
currently set up. Correct by 1/19/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.
